title: I've Played 160 Hours of Once Human - Review
author: Force Gaming

key_facts: FACT: The game officially launched this week and the reviewer has played over 150 hours across beta and launch phases.
FACT: Once Human is a shared open world looter shooter MMO with survival mechanics and a supernatural theme.
FACT: The open world is seamless with no loading screens except during fast travel or entering instance dungeons.
FACT: Players begin with a survival tutorial that introduces crafting, base building, and gathering systems.
FACT: Strongholds are large, themed zones (e.g., hospitals, factories, military compounds) with objectives like killing enemies and activating rift anchors.
FACT: Monolith bosses are high-level PVE encounters with multiple phases and mechanics, currently three in total with more planned for future seasons.
FACT: Silos are dungeon-like instances with multiple difficulty tiers, including solo, group, and hard modes, offering gear and resource rewards.
FACT: The game features dynamic world events such as fog events, jumping puzzles, roaming bosses, and public group challenges like the Disco event.
FACT: The game includes hidden mechanics like memory puzzles, emote mimics, and ripple-in-space-time triggers that reveal collectibles.
FACT: Players can build bases anywhere outside restricted zones, with full relocation possible after a 10-minute cooldown.
FACT: The Cradle system tracks crafting progression, mimetic mastery, and passive buffs tied to character development.
FACT: Deviations are collectible pets that provide unique buffs when kept satisfied through environmental adjustments.
FACT: The wish machine is a gacha-style system used for late-game gear progression, requiring star chrom currency to operate.
FACT: Star chrom is earned through weekly activities, base defense (Stardust Resonator), and seasonal reward tracks.
FACT: The game launched with no pay-to-win mechanics; all real-money purchases are cosmetic only.
key_opinions: OPINION: The game’s blend of genres creates a fresh and enjoyable experience despite its complexity.
OPINION: The open world design feels reminiscent of games like The Division and Defiance, but with better integration of player presence.
OPINION: The survival mechanics, especially sanity depletion, add meaningful depth to combat and exploration.
OPINION: The wish machine system, while not pay-to-win now, creates a dependency on RNG that could become problematic if monetized later.
OPINION: The sheer number of menus and progress trackers makes the game feel unnecessarily convoluted and frustrating to manage.
OPINION: The seasonal reset every 6 weeks is too short for long-term players and undermines sustained progression.
OPINION: The game’s combat is overly easy outside of specific content like monolith bosses and base defense mode.
OPINION: The floaty movement and melee mechanics detract from immersion and make combat feel unresponsive.
OPINION: The lack of key remapping for certain controls is a baffling limitation given the otherwise flexible UI.
OPINION: The privacy policy concerns are exaggerated, but still raise valid questions about data tracking practices.
key_datapoints: DATA: Over 150 hours of gameplay logged by the reviewer across beta and launch phases.
DATA: The game resets every 6 weeks with new seasons, resetting progression except for base blueprints and blueprints.
DATA: Players earn star chrom via weekly activities, Stardust Resonator base defense, and reward tracks.
DATA: The wish machine uses star chrom to generate random blueprints, with higher-tier items obtainable only through it.
DATA: The Stardust Resonator rewards up to a set amount of star chrom per week based on defense performance.
DATA: Players can place bases anywhere except near strongholds or on roads, with relocation allowed after 10 minutes.
DATA: Deviations require environmental customization (lighting, sound, temperature) to remain productive and happy.
DATA: The game has at least three known monolith bosses: Foul Shadow Hunter, Triant, and Arxium.
DATA: Eight separate progress-tracking menus exist, each requiring manual interaction to claim rewards.
DATA: The game launched with no pay-to-win mechanics; all real-money purchases are cosmetic only.
